node.bodyText:
Overall a nice job.

change a little bit strategy pattern
reimplement static factory method (you implemented factory method)
implement a copy() method of Person to create real deep copy

N: This is Logger class. So Logger should have log(), write() or smth like that.
Responsibility of creating logger should be in LoggerFactory
(maybe you confused with method naming)
N: createLogger

You have to format your code. You have code-styles problems that are not related to the logic of the code. Change it across all classes. It's important for real projects.
IntelliJ -> Code -> Reformat code.
To make it in all classes,

RMB (right mouse click on java folder)-> reformat code

In this way, you do shallow copy. To make deep copy here, you have to create a new object with new address based on state of current object.
There is a code practic in lecture meeting record.

This is Factory method pattern.
You need implement static factory method.
https://www.baeldung.com/java-constructors-vs-static-factory-methods
This was a homework example of bad code to build a "Strategy" pattern on

Navigator should have a field of RouteStrategy routeStrategy.
and calculateRoute() method that accept destination and use this routeStrategy to calculate route (and you can set different routes) or pass via constructior needed route strategy -- newBusRouteStrategy, etc

N: just return some value.
It's a bad practice to modify arguments.
https://chat.openai.com/share/e2185127-e066-4d5f-8d50-bdb8c1a87e51

node.title: Create alerta.py
node.body:
# EditRead1
Codul urmator este doar o parte din proiectul de casa final. Acesta ar trebui sa indeplineasca urmatoarea functie: de a transmite un mesaj de alert automat pe telegram in cazul in care cineva incearca sa patrunda intr-o locuinta daca nu a satisfacut cerintele sistemului de securitate.
1) CE TREBUIE INSTALAT
 - pentru a rula acest cod trebuie instalata biblioteca requests din terminalul mediului de programare in care lucrati. Pentru instalare biblioteci folositi urmatoarea comanda: pip install requests sau python -m pip install requests.
2) CUM SE RULEAZA
 - rularea programului se face apasand pe butonul de run din partea superioara a ecranului (in cazul in care folositi Pycharm) sau Run->Run Module (daca folositi Python IDLE)
3) REFERINTE RELEVANTE
- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hHQu4O9OnVo
- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=URPIZZNr_2M
- https://chat.openai.com/share/4d0a8dca-6bb5-41d2-89af-977259f9a3ca

node.title: Updated to include webhook subscription
node.body:
Updated Webhook for malware scanning to include handling of subscription.

## Description
The existing webhook functionality only handled the actual update of file status based on malware scan result.
This update will handle subscription requests so that Azure can actually connect to the webhook.

## Related Issue(s)
- #220

## Verification
- [x] **Your** code builds clean without any errors or warnings
- [x] Manual testing done (required)
- [x] Relevant automated test added (if you find this hard, leave it and we'll help out)
- [x] All tests run green

## Documentation
- [x] User documentation is updated with a separate linked PR in [altinn-studio-docs.](https://github.com/Altinn/altinn-studio-docs) (if applicable)

node.title: Add support for `CollapsedDocStrings` in `@meta` block
node.body:
Setting `DocStringsCollapsed = true` in the `@meta` block of a particular page essentially clicks the "Collapse all docstrings" in the navigation bar after the page loads, collapsing all docstrings on that page.

I think the approach of just having JavaScript click the collapse button is the right one here: First, I'm not sure that it would be possible to write out the page in a collapsed state, or at least not without doing some pretty gnarly rewrites of the `HTMLWriter`. More importantly, rendering the page expanded and then collapsing it with JavaScript seems like the right thing to do from an accessibility standpoint: We'd want the page to still be useful without JavaScript. I've been known to access API documentation in the terminal with `w3m`, so not relying on JavaScript to render the core content is something I actually care about. Screenreaders probably also wouldn't like if all docstrings initially rendered as `hidden`.

Closes #2282

nodes.bodyText: With respect to #2282, this PR does not implement a global flag for collapsing all docstrings. It's not something I'm interested in, although it wouldn't be terribly hard to add it in (but definitely more work to document and test)

I added collapse-by-default to the Internal API pages, e.g., https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/lib/internals/anchors/
Interestingly (and unlike in my previous local testing), I'm finding that it doesn't seem completely reliable. Maybe I'll have to revise the JS a bit. It might be running too early or something.

One other thing: I'm a little bit skeptical of putting too many writer-specific options into the top-level scope of an at-meta block. Should we have some way to namespace writer-specific options like this? Not sure what the best syntax would be, but maybe something like:
Writer.HTML = begin
    CollapsedDocStrings = true
end

I'm a little bit skeptical of putting too many writer-specific options into the top-level scope of an at-meta block.

I have no strong feelings on this either way. Although I'd probably keep it flat, mostly because EditURL, Description, and maybe Draft would also seem to belong with Writer.HTML, but moving them is probably breaking compatibility.
Assuming I can make get the CollapsedDocStrings to work reliably at all, maybe we can mark it as "experimental" and then move it to a namespaced scheme afterward, in a separate PR.

Okay, this is back on track now, and could be merged in principle.
We can still tweak this, of course, maybe changing the animation speed, but that's optional as far as I'm concerned (edit: done).
As before, https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/lib/internals/anchors/ (and the other "internals" pages) demo the feature.

I think I'm okay with the collapse being visible. It's a bit jarring, but fast enough, and we can try to improve on it in the future. It's opt-in for the author anyway.
However, there seems to be some bug when you navigate to the page without a hard-refresh? This was from the preview deployment:

  
    
    

    screen-2024-01-25_15.10.18.mp4

It's a bit hard to tell what's going on in the video (even if I step through it frame by frame). The way it should work is that if you reload a page, or navigate to a page, the docstrings always get collapsed. What I think I'm seeing in your video looks a little like how things were at the previous (broken) attempt. Did you clear your browser cache? I was definitely seeing wonky behavior until I did that. But now, everything is working to my expectations without any fail, both on Safari and Chrome.
I'll try to record a little video of how things are looking on my end tomorrow or so. Or else, it would have to be a platform/browser issue. Is that Chrome on Linux?
As for the animation, that looks about correct in the video. You still see the full content flash very briefly before it collapses, even with an animation time of zero. It don't know if it's less jarring if it's a slower animation. That might be something we can decide with a screenshare at the next community call.

I think I'm seeing in your video looks a little like how things were at the previous (broken) attempt.

I also think it might be running old code too.
Although, I think the animation should be slow instead of just plain 0. That's just my 2 cents though!😅

Did you clear your browser cache?

Good point, I didn't. However, even after clearing the cache, I see the issue. I also tried in incognito. The only way I can get it to work is to disable the cache altogether.. so it does seem like it might cache-related.. but maybe some sort of a race condition?
Just something to double check: is the JS in https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/ up to date?
And yes, it's on Chrome & Linux. But I also see the issue in Firefox, where I hadn't opened the page before.

It don't know if it's less jarring if it's a slower animation.

Slower would be more jarring (I think). But as I said, I think it's good enough. What we'd ideally have is no animation.

What we'd ideally have is no animation.

For what it's worth, the themeswap actually has the same problem, and it solves it by making sure it runs early. But it's not immediately clear how complex it would be to do something similar here.

This is how it looks on my end, very reliably, both in Safari and Chrome, as well as on an iPad

  
    
    

    CleanShot.2024-01-28.at.19.12.34-converted.mp4
    
  

  

  


This is using the latest JS in https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/ which hasn't changed since #2394 (comment)

so it does seem like it might cache-related.. but maybe some sort of a race condition?

Very strange. I wonder if there's a ISP/router cache or CDN or something getting in the way. But since the problem disappears when you disable the browser cache, that doesn't seem to be it.
I guess we might still have some kind of JS concurrency bug, although @Hetarth02's solution really seems to me like it should work reliably, and click the collapse button only after everything else has loaded. I'm not a JS expert, though.

I noticed I'm getting these in the console when it's not working:
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'docstringscollapsed')
    at documenter.js:238:10
    at Object.execCb (require.min.js:1:16727)
    at e.check (require.min.js:1:10499)
    at e.<anonymous> (require.min.js:1:12915)
    at require.min.js:1:1542
    at require.min.js:1:13376
    at each (require.min.js:1:1020)
    at e.emit (require.min.js:1:13344)
    at e.check (require.min.js:1:11058)
    at e.enable (require.min.js:1:13242)
documenter.js:704 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'addEventListener')
    at documenter.js:704:45
    at Object.execCb (require.min.js:1:16727)
    at e.check (require.min.js:1:10499)
    at e.enable (require.min.js:1:13242)
    at e.init (require.min.js:1:9605)
    at require.min.js:1:15109
Ah, that at least gives us something to work with!
With the fixes, it looks like it works now! @Hetarth02, are you still seeing the mobile search/sidebar issue you mentioned on Slack?
@mortenpi I just checked, everything seems to be working fine.
I have no preferences on the name of the option. Looks good to me!
Then let's merge it! Thank you @goerz and @Hetarth02 for iterating on this!

I'm sorry. How is this keyword supposed to be used? Searching the Documenter docs leads me to the release notes page, than to these PRs, but there is not (as far as I could find) documentation on how to use these options.

Are you using the master branch version of Documenter? Because this has not been released yet.
If yes, then the relevant documentation would be here: https://documenter.juliadocs.org/dev/man/syntax/#@meta-block and an example is here: https://github.com/JuliaDocs/Documenter.jl/blob/master/docs/src/lib/internals/anchors.md (raw)

Uhm, this in the release notes of 1.0.0, so that got me confused:

Added the ability to expand/collapse individual as well as all docstrings. (#1393, #2078)
That’s referring to the feature of being able to collapse and expand docstrings manually

node.bodyText:
I feel that ideally we'd do this by statically generating the necessary HTML. It looks like we use display: none on the section tags.. and then update some other stuff. Ideally, we'd have a class on the article tag that toggles everything.
How much effort would you be willing to put into this? I didn't test this yet, but I assume that this works, and we can merge this as is, and refactor later as well.

More importantly, rendering the page expanded and then collapsing it with JavaScript seems like the right thing to do from an accessibility standpoint: We'd want the page to still be useful without JavaScript.

Ah.. that is a fair point actually. We should indeed make sure that it loads uncollapsed if you don't have JS enabled. So now I'm coming around to this approach.

Right. I'd still advocate for going with the approach in this PR. I started out with trying to write out the collapsed HTML if the option is set until I realized that:
(a) It's much more difficult to implement that way. In fact, I'm not sure that I'd be able to do it in any reasonable amount of time.
(b) "Collapsed" means display: none, which removes the content entirely without JS, which seems like a bad idea.
The test in the PR only checks for the presence of the injected JS. I don't think there's much I can do beyond that. I did test locally that the JS does what it's supposed to (very nicely, in fact). What I could do as an additional test is to use the feature in the Documenter documentation. Maybe collapsing all the Internal API pages by default?

Yeah, let's go with the JS approach.
It currently does have the problem that you can see all the docstrings collapsing when you navigate to the page though. Maybe @Hetarth02 has some ideas how to work around that.
Interesting, I will definitely take a look into this.

@Hetarth02 I'd appreciate that! You might be better at JS than me. I'm having real trouble getting it to load correctly. In my first iteration, it worked fine locally but only 90% of the time in Chrome and only 1% of the time in Safari. I'm guessing the script was running too early. In the current iteration, I've tried to move the <script> tag to the end of the file, but that's still behaving the same way (i.e., not working in Safari). I also tried putting it in an external script (I think local scripts load before external scripts, which may be part of the problem), but that was much more complicated to implement, and then just didn't work at all. I can push that branch again somewhere if you'd like to take a look at it.

It currently does have the problem that you can see all the docstrings collapsing when you navigate to the page though

Yeah, I can't decide whether it's a problem or whether I actually kinda like it. But in any case, I think jQuery is handling the collapse animation. Maybe there's a way to temporarily disable the animation or at least speed it up?

Yes, Jquery handles the animation and there is a way to speed it up.
I also think that, initially appearing as open then getting closed is okay.

I can push that branch again

Pushed to https://github.com/JuliaDocs/Documenter.jl/tree/mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed2. This one doesn't work at all, though, and I'm not sure why.

I'm somewhat out of my depth when it comes to JS. Does anything from the discussion I had with ChatGPT seem useful here? https://chat.openai.com/share/a5c0b599-79f0-46e5-9840-74984896d398
The suggestion

Modify documenter.js to dispatch a custom event when it has fully loaded and executed. Then, in your script at the end of the page, add an event listener for this custom event before executing your code.

doesn't sound entirely implausible.

@goerz Which branch should I check from?
mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed2 or mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed

Preferably, mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed. The other one was an attempt to put the JS in a separate script file. It was both more complicated and didn't actually work, but I just wanted to keep the branch around in case mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed doesn't work out and I need to get back to it.

mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed works perfectly when looking at documentation locally with LiveServer, but doesn't work reliably when looking at the online documentation, e.g. at https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/lib/internals/anchors/. In Chrome, it works most of the time, in Safari, it does not work most of the time. Presumably, the issue is the asynchronous execution of JS and the code that clicks the collapse button firing too early.
That sounds good! Do you want to just push to the mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed branch? I'm assuming you have permissions – or make a new branch, if you prefer.
I don't think I have the necessary permissions to do so.
I can merge from https://github.com/Hetarth02/Documenter.jl/ into my PR then. Let me know which branch.
Alright, will do so. Let me iron some things out and will ping you when I am done.
@goerz Sorry for the delay, I have pushed the changes to Draft-PR-2394. Also, made an PR to this branch.
No worries! Thanks for taking a look! I'll check it out.
@goerz Just FYI, this is just a rudimentary implementation from my side. There is of course room for improvement in logic.😅
It works perfectly! Thanks for coming up with the approach that makes this reliable!

This seems fine to me. It still shows the close-animation after the page is loaded. I don't mind it that much, but @mortenpi might still prefer if we speed it up.
@Hetarth02 Do you know what to add to control the animation speed?
Seems a little unrelated to the PR, but I just kept it in
Marked as "experimental" so we can still change this even after the PR is merged/released. For example, #2394 (comment)

I think I figured it out: e5b84d3
The currently deployed preview documentation disables the animation completely. Better? I'm okay with either.
This whole thing probably needs to be in a $(document).ready(function () { ... }?
Let's try it! https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/ should now have that change. Of course, all I can say is that it continues to work for me, so you'll have to let us know :-)

Eh, yea, let's just keep it on the top-level. Doing namespacing adds other kinds of complexity. Some of these options will just be ignored by some backends.
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            - `DocStringsCollapsed`: if `true`, collapse all docstrings after loading the page (experimental).
          
          
            
            - `DocStringsCollapsed`: for output formats that support this (i.e. only [`HTML`](@ref Documenter.HTML) currently), if set to `true`, render all docstrings as collapsed by default.
@goerz I took the liberty of pushing a DocStringsCollapsed -> CollapsedDocString bikeshed. Happy to revert it if you prefer DocStringsCollapsed. From my side, I'm happy if we merge this!
